output.conclusion: This course provides a solid foundation for intermediate-level aerospace engineering concepts. Further exploration in specialized areas is highly recommended.
output.introduction: Welcome to the intermediate-level Aerospace Engineering course! This course builds upon fundamental principles and delves into more complex topics relevant to the design, analysis, and operation of aerospace vehicles.

chapters.description: Review of basic airfoil theory, lift and drag coefficients, pressure distribution, and stall characteristics. Introduction to different airfoil families and their applications.
Finite wing theory, induced drag, aspect ratio effects, wingtip vortices, and lift distribution. Introduction to wing design considerations for different flight regimes.
Analysis of flaps, slats, and other high-lift devices. Impact on lift and drag characteristics. Design considerations for takeoff and landing performance.
Review of rocket propulsion principles, thrust equation, specific impulse, and nozzle design. Introduction to different types of rocket engines.
Components and operation of liquid rocket engines, propellant feed systems, combustion chambers, and nozzle design. Introduction to different propellant combinations.
Components and operation of solid rocket motors, propellant grain design, ignition systems, and nozzle design. Introduction to different solid propellant formulations.
Review of Kepler's laws of planetary motion, orbital elements, and coordinate systems. Introduction to orbital maneuvers and trajectory design.
Hohmann transfer, bi-elliptic transfer, and other orbital maneuvers. Calculation of delta-V requirements and maneuver durations.
Aerodynamic heating, deceleration profiles, and trajectory design for atmospheric entry. Introduction to thermal protection systems.
